bibl.title: Memorandum from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, May 11, 1924

div1.p: Carter suggests topics for a possible paper.

div1.head: Memorandum from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, May 11, 1924
div1.opener:
Miscl
Deeks
/LC
Memorandum.
May 11/24.
Dear Doctor Deeks:
div1.p:
I was hoping not to have a paper--that taking part in the de-
bates would be sufficient. I usually have been very free in this
latter. The reason for the first is that I have been putting all
of the time I have been able to work since January 1st. in writing
papers: or memoranda of one sort or another.

However, if you think that I ought to write a paper, I could
present one on any of the following subjects:

1/ The work the I. H. B. is doing for the elimination of yel-
low fever from the world.

I am still on the Yellow Fever Council and in close consulta-
tion with them and probably know more about it than anyone save
Russell. If this is already covered by some of their own men, I
could make an exposé on

2/ The Place of Origin of Yellow Fever, and the possible
effect in its determination on itsthe prophylaxis of Yellow Fever.

3/ The witness which the early history of yellow fever bears
to the spontaneous elimination (by "Failure of the Human Host??)
of the disease in the American tropics.

4/ I wonder would a very short paper on the evidence against
the pre-Columbian prevalenceexistence of malaria in America be of more inter-
rst than the yellow fever matters? I I think it would, but the objec-
tion to my writing it is that I wrote a Memorandum (really for the
personal edification of a friend of mine & to show Schwellengreble)
on this matter last year, which has been published as an editorial
in the Southern Medical Journal and while I don't suppose this has
any international circulation, yet it was published. Malaria should
be of more present interest than yellow fever to your Conference,
which latter disease will soon, I hope, be in the past.

5/ I could speak a piece from notes--I would scarcely have
data enough to write it--on the “Preferential and Compulsary
Breeding Places of Some Disease-bearing Mosquitoes (Anopheles on Stegomyia aegypti. and the Limits
that Determine the Latter.” It would be short, but new and, I think,
suggestive. It would take three to six months work to do justice
to the subject and yet it might be worth while to start people
thinking in that direction.

If you think I ought to write a paper, please choose which
one, and give me notice, so that if it be of one of the first
three, I would have time to take it up with the Rockefeller people.
Indeed, I would have to have time for preparation for any of the
others also.
With very best remembrances to you all, in which Laura joins
